content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Solvable in 5 minutes, and complex enough that I submitted incorrect code twice.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Enjoyed it! Well structured.

I liked it for Shortest!
Just some suggestions for the test cases:
 - Since 0 < N ≤ 10, it might be a good idea to have both test cases for n=1 and n=10
 - Maybe adding a "simmetrical" test for the "Progressive Resistance" test would be a good idea? (ie, a test in which all values are decreasing)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Well built, fast and fun

Goal
* Please change "H <= D" to descriptive text to avoid giving away a hint of what code to use.

* Please format all variable names (D, N, H) as [[variables]].

* Please format "RETREAT" as a {{constant}} and remove the quotation marks.

Input
* Please format "Line 1", "Line 2" and "Next N lines" in <<bold>>.

* Please format "D", "N" (including within "Next N lines") and "H" as [[variables]].

Output
* Please format "RETREAT" as a {{constant}} and remove the quotation marks.

Constraints
* Please format "D", "N" and "H" as [[variables]].

* Please change 100 to 10 because N is never greater than 10 in any cases.

Cases
* Each test and its validator should cover the same scenario with similar inputs (including the magnitude). Please revise the cases accordingly. You may have more than 4 pairs of cases if necessary.

Thanks.

Hi! Thanks for the detailed feedback.

I have applied all the requested changes:

Goal: Replaced the formula with descriptive text and applied the requested formatting.

Input/Output: Added the bold formatting and variable tags as requested.

Constraints: Updated N to 10 and formatted the variables.

Cases: I reorganized the tests and validators into matching pairs that cover the same scenarios and magnitudes.

The puzzle is updated and ready for review !

Thanks a lot for your suggestions!
Yes, for a Clash of Code, having those additional edge cases would definitely be a +:

Tests with N = 1 and N = 10 → ensures coverage of both extremes

A symmetrical decreasing version of the progressive resistance test → great idea to catch opposite logic flaws

I’ll consider adding them, thanks again for the helpful feedback!

It's better now. The cases could use a few more improvements.

* At the moment, the expected output is identical between the test and its validator in 3 out of the 4 pairs. For the cases where the output is an index, it'd be better to introduce a bit more variation.

* For the last pair, could you revise

  • Progress Resistance: use larger input values (similar to the validator) while still preserving the "progressive resistance" pattern,
  
  * Max Values: have its input values in ascending order so that it also reflects progressive resistance?

Thanks.

I have updated the cases as requested:

Variation: The expected outputs for the Validators in pairs 1 and 3 are now different from their corresponding Tests (output 0 vs output 3/1).

Pair 4 (Progressive & Max):

I updated the Test Case to use large values (up to 10,000) while keeping the progressive pattern.

I updated the Validator to be in ascending order to reflect the progressive resistance pattern perfectly.

Everything should be good now !
